trans-unit.source: Multi-tenant applications with elastic database tools and row-level security
trans-unit.target: Multi-tenant applications with elastic database tools and row-level security

trans-unit.source: Learn how to use elastic database tools together with row-level security to build an application with a highly scalable data tier on Azure SQL Database that supports multi-tenant shards.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to use elastic database tools together with row-level security to build an application with a highly scalable data tier on Azure SQL Database that supports multi-tenant shards.

trans-unit.source: Multi-tenant applications with elastic database tools and row-level security
trans-unit.target: Multi-tenant applications with elastic database tools and row-level security

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Elastic database tools</linkText><title></title></link> and <link><linkText>row-level security (RLS)</linkText><title></title></link> offer a powerful set of capabilities for flexibly and efficiently scaling the data tier of a multi-tenant application with Azure SQL Database.
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Elastic database tools</linkText><title></title></link> and <link><linkText>row-level security (RLS)</linkText><title></title></link> offer a powerful set of capabilities for flexibly and efficiently scaling the data tier of a multi-tenant application with Azure SQL Database.

trans-unit.source: This article illustrates how to use these technologies together to build an application with a highly scalable data tier that supports multi-tenant shards, using ADO.NET SqlClient and/or Entity Framework.
trans-unit.target: This article illustrates how to use these technologies together to build an application with a highly scalable data tier that supports multi-tenant shards, using ADO.NET SqlClient and/or Entity Framework.

trans-unit.source: Elastic database tools enables developers to scale out the data tier of an application via industry-standard sharding practices using a set of .NET libraries and Azure service templates.
trans-unit.target: Elastic database tools enables developers to scale out the data tier of an application via industry-standard sharding practices using a set of .NET libraries and Azure service templates.

trans-unit.source: Managing shards with using the Elastic Database Client Library helps automate and streamline many of the infrastructural tasks typically associated with sharding.
trans-unit.target: Managing shards with using the Elastic Database Client Library helps automate and streamline many of the infrastructural tasks typically associated with sharding.

trans-unit.source: Row-level security enables developers to store data for multiple tenants in the same database using security policies to filter out rows that do not belong to the tenant executing a query.
trans-unit.target: Row-level security enables developers to store data for multiple tenants in the same database using security policies to filter out rows that do not belong to the tenant executing a query.

trans-unit.source: Centralizing access logic with RLS inside the database, rather than in the application, simplifies maintenance and reduces the risk of error as an application’s codebase grows.
trans-unit.target: Centralizing access logic with RLS inside the database, rather than in the application, simplifies maintenance and reduces the risk of error as an application’s codebase grows.

trans-unit.source: RLS requires the latest <link><linkText>Azure SQL Database update (V12)</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: RLS requires the latest <link><linkText>Azure SQL Database update (V12)</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Using these features together, an application can benefit from cost savings and efficiency gains by storing data for multiple tenants in the same shard database.
trans-unit.target: Using these features together, an application can benefit from cost savings and efficiency gains by storing data for multiple tenants in the same shard database.

trans-unit.source: At the same time, an application still has the flexibility to offer isolated, single-tenant shards for “premium” tenants who require stricter performance guarantees since multi-tenant shards do not guarantee equal resource distribution among tenants.
trans-unit.target: At the same time, an application still has the flexibility to offer isolated, single-tenant shards for “premium” tenants who require stricter performance guarantees since multi-tenant shards do not guarantee equal resource distribution among tenants.

trans-unit.source: In short, the elastic database client library’s <link><linkText>data dependent routing</linkText><title></title></link> APIs automatically connect tenants to the correct shard database containing their sharding key (generally a “TenantId”).
trans-unit.target: In short, the elastic database client library’s <link><linkText>data dependent routing</linkText><title></title></link> APIs automatically connect tenants to the correct shard database containing their sharding key (generally a “TenantId”).

trans-unit.source: Once connected, an RLS security policy within the database ensures that tenants can only access rows that contain their TenantId.
trans-unit.target: Once connected, an RLS security policy within the database ensures that tenants can only access rows that contain their TenantId.

trans-unit.source: It is assumed that all tables contain a TenantId column to indicate which rows belong to each tenant.
trans-unit.target: It is assumed that all tables contain a TenantId column to indicate which rows belong to each tenant.

trans-unit.source: Application tier: Modify the application code to always set CONTEXT_INFO to the current TenantId after opening a connection.
trans-unit.target: Application tier: Modify the application code to always set CONTEXT_INFO to the current TenantId after opening a connection.

trans-unit.source: The sample project has already done this.
trans-unit.target: The sample project has already done this.

trans-unit.source: Data tier: Create an RLS security policy in each shard database to filter rows based on the value of CONTEXT_INFO.
trans-unit.target: Data tier: Create an RLS security policy in each shard database to filter rows based on the value of CONTEXT_INFO.

trans-unit.source: You will need to do this for each of your shard databases, otherwise rows in multi-tenant shards will not be filtered.
trans-unit.target: You will need to do this for each of your shard databases, otherwise rows in multi-tenant shards will not be filtered.

trans-unit.source: Step 1) Application tier: Set CONTEXT_INFO to TenantId
trans-unit.target: Step 1) Application tier: Set CONTEXT_INFO to TenantId

trans-unit.source: After connecting to a shard database using the elastic database client library’s data dependent routing APIs, the application still needs to tell the database which TenantId is using that connection so that an RLS security policy can filter out rows belonging to other tenants.
trans-unit.target: After connecting to a shard database using the elastic database client library’s data dependent routing APIs, the application still needs to tell the database which TenantId is using that connection so that an RLS security policy can filter out rows belonging to other tenants.

trans-unit.source: The recommended way to pass this information is to set <link><linkText>CONTEXT_INFO</linkText><title></title></link> to the current TenantId for that connection.
trans-unit.target: The recommended way to pass this information is to set <link><linkText>CONTEXT_INFO</linkText><title></title></link> to the current TenantId for that connection.

trans-unit.source: Note that on Azure SQL Database, CONTEXT_INFO is pre-populated with a session-specific GUID, so you must set CONTEXT_INFO to the correct TenantId before executing any queries on a new connection to ensure that no rows are inadvertently leaked.
trans-unit.target: Note that on Azure SQL Database, CONTEXT_INFO is pre-populated with a session-specific GUID, so you must set CONTEXT_INFO to the correct TenantId before executing any queries on a new connection to ensure that no rows are inadvertently leaked.

trans-unit.target: Entity Framework

trans-unit.target: Before returning the connection brokered through data dependent routing, simply create and execute a SqlCommand that sets CONTEXT_INFO to the shardingKey (TenantId) specified for that connection.

trans-unit.source: This way, you only need to write code once to set CONTEXT_INFO.

trans-unit.target: ADO.NET SqlClient

trans-unit.source: For applications using ADO.NET SqlClient, the recommended approach is to create a wrapper function around ShardMap.OpenConnectionForKey() that automatically sets CONTEXT_INFO to the correct TenantId before returning a connection.
trans-unit.target: For applications using ADO.NET SqlClient, the recommended approach is to create a wrapper function around ShardMap.OpenConnectionForKey() that automatically sets CONTEXT_INFO to the correct TenantId before returning a connection.

trans-unit.source: To ensure that CONTEXT_INFO is always set properly, you should only open connections using this wrapper function.
trans-unit.target: To ensure that CONTEXT_INFO is always set properly, you should only open connections using this wrapper function.

trans-unit.target: Step 2) Data tier: Create row-level security policy and constraints

trans-unit.source: Create a security policy to filter SELECT, UPDATE, and DELETE queries
trans-unit.target: Create a security policy to filter SELECT, UPDATE, and DELETE queries

trans-unit.source: Now that the application is setting CONTEXT_INFO to the current TenantId before querying, an RLS security policy can filter queries and exclude rows that have a different TenantId.
trans-unit.target: Now that the application is setting CONTEXT_INFO to the current TenantId before querying, an RLS security policy can filter queries and exclude rows that have a different TenantId.

trans-unit.source: RLS is implemented in T-SQL: a user-defined predicate function defines the filtering logic, and a security policy binds this function to any number of tables.
trans-unit.target: RLS is implemented in T-SQL: a user-defined predicate function defines the filtering logic, and a security policy binds this function to any number of tables.

trans-unit.source: For this project, the predicate function will simply verify that the application (rather than some other SQL user) is connected to the database, and that the value of CONTEXT_INFO matches the TenantId of a given row.
trans-unit.target: For this project, the predicate function will simply verify that the application (rather than some other SQL user) is connected to the database, and that the value of CONTEXT_INFO matches the TenantId of a given row.

trans-unit.source: Rows that meet these conditions will be allowed through the filter for SELECT, UPDATE, and DELETE queries.
trans-unit.target: Rows that meet these conditions will be allowed through the filter for SELECT, UPDATE, and DELETE queries.

trans-unit.source: Add check constraints to block wrong-tenant INSERTs and UPDATEs
trans-unit.target: Add check constraints to block wrong-tenant INSERTs and UPDATEs

trans-unit.source: At present, RLS security policies will not prevent the application from accidentally inserting rows for the wrong TenantId, or updating the TenantId of a visible row to be a new value.
trans-unit.target: At present, RLS security policies will not prevent the application from accidentally inserting rows for the wrong TenantId, or updating the TenantId of a visible row to be a new value.

trans-unit.source: For some applications, such as read-only reporting apps, this is not a problem.
trans-unit.target: For some applications, such as read-only reporting apps, this is not a problem.

trans-unit.source: However, since this application allows tenants to insert new blogs, it is worthwhile to create an additional safeguard that throws an error if the application code mistakenly tries to insert or update rows such that violate the filter predicate.
trans-unit.target: However, since this application allows tenants to insert new blogs, it is worthwhile to create an additional safeguard that throws an error if the application code mistakenly tries to insert or update rows such that violate the filter predicate.

trans-unit.source: As described in <link><linkText>Row-Level Security: Blocking unauthorized INSERTs (blog)</linkText><title></title></link>, the recommended solution is to create a check constraint on each table to enforce the same RLS filter predicate for insert and update operations.
trans-unit.target: As described in <link><linkText>Row-Level Security: Blocking unauthorized INSERTs (blog)</linkText><title></title></link>, the recommended solution is to create a check constraint on each table to enforce the same RLS filter predicate for insert and update operations.

trans-unit.source: Maintenance
trans-unit.target: Maintenance

trans-unit.source: Adding new shards: You must execute the T-SQL script to enable RLS (and add check constraints) on any new shards, otherwise queries on these shards will not be filtered.
trans-unit.target: Adding new shards: You must execute the T-SQL script to enable RLS (and add check constraints) on any new shards, otherwise queries on these shards will not be filtered.

trans-unit.source: Adding new tables: You must add a filter predicate to the security policy on all shards whenever a new table is created, otherwise queries on the new table will not be filtered.
trans-unit.target: Adding new tables: You must add a filter predicate to the security policy on all shards whenever a new table is created, otherwise queries on the new table will not be filtered.

trans-unit.source: This can be automated using a DDL trigger, as described in <link><linkText>Apply Row-Level Security automatically to newly created tables (blog)</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: This can be automated using a DDL trigger, as described in <link><linkText>Apply Row-Level Security automatically to newly created tables (blog)</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Summary
trans-unit.target: Summary

trans-unit.source: Elastic database tools and row-level security can be used together to scale out an application’s data tier with support for both multi-tenant and single-tenant shards.
trans-unit.target: Elastic database tools and row-level security can be used together to scale out an application’s data tier with support for both multi-tenant and single-tenant shards.

trans-unit.source: Multi-tenant shards can be used to store data more efficiently (particularly in cases where a large number of tenants have only a few rows of data), while single-tenant shards can be used to support premium tenants with stricter performance and isolation requirements.
trans-unit.target: Multi-tenant shards can be used to store data more efficiently (particularly in cases where a large number of tenants have only a few rows of data), while single-tenant shards can be used to support premium tenants with stricter performance and isolation requirements.
